question: Come on, come on. Here they come, Gallagher! Here they come! There's the third one. If I don't get the last one, there's a certain sob sister I know that's going to get a kick right in the . . . oh! Whoops, almost had that.
answer: What? The screen?

question: Gallagher! I made it!
answer: Come over here!

question: Look, I quit!
answer: Yeah?

question: Yeah.
answer: Yeah?

question: You're always picking on me. It took me three hours to get those little gadgets in those holes, and you screw it up in a minute. Hey, look!
answer: Aagh! No wonder you're batty. Would it be imposing too much upon you if I asked you to do a little work today? Just to sort of break the monotony?

question: With me you can always do business.
answer: Do you know what to do in a drawing-room?

question: It isn't a question of knowing what to do, it's knowing how to get in one that counts. Gloria Golden?
answer: Yeah, little Gloria.

question: The human cash register. Got her hooks into the Schuyler kid, eh?
answer: Right - for the first time this year. Come on, get going, get going! Yeah - and get us into a million dollar libel suit. It wouldn't be the first time. Now, you get over there and get a statement out of the old lady, the sister, or the kid. Any of them - but get it. What expenses? All you need is carfare to Long Island. You'd better get a shave and a shine, because you, you're going to have a tough time getting in there as it is.

question: Imbecile!
answer: You should have known better than to write, Romeo. I found that out a long time ago.

question: I should say you had. At the rate you two are going, we'll have to leave the country to save our faces.
answer: Splendid, Mother. Let's hop over to Monte Carlo. It's a great place to save a face.

question: Say, take it easy! Take it easy! Listen, my boy. No use you hanging around here. Just buy the Tribune tonight and read all about it. You can rewrite it for your last edition.
answer: Couldn't make the last edition. It'd take me four hours to translate your story into English.

question: Oh, is that so?
answer: I'm afraid.

question: Hey, make up your mind, will you? Hi, folks! What's the matter? Isn't there a 'bless you' in the crowd?
answer: You're the Tribune man?

question: Yeah, hello. How are you? Thanks, I will.
answer: This way.

question: Oh, man! Oh, boy!
answer: Fine newspaper the Tribune.

question: Well, I should say!
answer: I knew your managing editor very well.

question: Is that so?
answer: Yale '21, I believe. We were classmates.

question: What's the matter? She got a cold?
answer: I got him his job on the paper. I'm a stock-holder, you know.

question: Is that so?
answer: As one Tribune man to another But right now I'm acting in the capacity of Mrs. Schuyler's attorney.

question: Oh, that's all right with me. I won't hold it against you. But you see, I'm here to find out about
answer: I know, I know. But there's no truth in the story whatsoever.

question: Oh yeah?
answer: So, you see how silly that rumor is?

question: Why, sure. It's a lotta hooey.
answer: That's what I wanted to say, but I couldn't think of it. Thank you very much.

question: All right, all right, don't mention it.
answer: Give my regards to your managing editor.

question: I certainly will. Well, so long folks! Thanks! Thanks.
answer: Smythe, bring in the other reporter.

question: Schuyler's the name, I presume? Yes, thank you, thank you. My name's Smith - Stewart Smith. No relation to John, Joe, Trade or Mark. Of course you can't have everything. Nice set of Conrads you have out there, Mrs. Schuyler. I was just glancing through this one.
answer: Just a habit. Mr. Schuyler is a bit put out by all the rumors going around.

question: Rumors? Rumors? Since when is a breach-of-promise case a rumor?
answer: No breach-of-promise case has been filed. The matter has been settled out of court.

question: Oh, so you did give her ten thousand dollars, eh? and there are letters . Well, well. That takes it out of the rumor class, doesn't it?
answer: We admit nothing. However, I have a little statement all prepared.

question: A statement? Good.
answer: I have it here.

question: Good. Don't you know you should never offer a newspaper man more than two dollars? If you do, he'll think it's counterfeit. I don't need fifty dollars. As a matter of fact, I've got fifty dollars.
answer: The man from the Tribune seemed perfectly satisfied.

question: Who, Bingy? Yeah, Bingy would. He never saw fifty dollars before. You could have bought him for six bits. Funny thing about Bingy. The more he gets - the more he prints. He looks stupid, doesn't he? But oh how smart he gets when he bends over a typewriter. So ten grand was the amount you gave the girl? Any other statement you folks would like to make? Wait a minute. Don't get excited. I wouldn't worry about it. A little publicity never hurt anybody.
answer: I think you'd better go.

question: I'm sure you're quite willing to be decent about this.
answer: Decent? Why Miss Schuyler, I want to be noble.

question: You're not going to print this silly thing, are you? Because my name's Schuyler too. And I haven't done a thing, but I'll suffer with Michael. And so will Mother.
answer: Mother's suffering already!

question: As a special favor to me, you won't print that story, will you?
answer: You know something, lady, if you sold life insurance, I'd go for a policy in sixty seconds.

question: Oh, thank you, I knew you'd understand.
answer: May I use your telephone? You're all right. Hello, Beekman 1300? Say, I interviewed a swell guy the other day - Einstein. Swell guy, a little eccentric, but swell. Doesn't wear any garters. Neither do I as a matter of fact. What good are garters anyway? Now wait a minute. Just hold on. Keep your shirt on. I'm coming to that. The Schuylers admit the story is true. Right. They gave the gal ten thousand bucks. But she's got some letters - and she's holding out for more dough - and it looks to me like she's going to get it. and she walked up to me and put her hand on my shoulder and said,

question: May I use your telephone? You're all right. Hello, Beekman 1300? Say, I interviewed a swell guy the other day - Einstein. Swell guy, a little eccentric, but swell. Doesn't wear any garters. Neither do I as a matter of fact. What good are garters anyway? Now wait a minute. Just hold on. Keep your shirt on. I'm coming to that. The Schuylers admit the story is true. Right. They gave the gal ten thousand bucks. But she's got some letters - and she's holding out for more dough - and it looks to me like she's going to get it. and she walked up to me and put her hand on my shoulder and said,
answer: You're sure going to be poison to that Junior Leaguer from now on!

question: I hope not . . . I've got to call on her this morning!
answer: You what?

question: Sure, I must drop in on the mad wench. Her wounds need soothing.
answer: For heaven's sake, Stew, are you completely bats? What for? I thought the story was cold. You can't go back there.

question: Sure, the story is cold, but I'm not. I'm sizzling - look! Psst! And with it came love! Oh Gallagher, you've got to meet her. She's it
answer: and that Well, I've seen her pictures, and I don't think she's so hot. Of course I haven't got a nose.

question: Gallagher! She's the real McCoy!
answer: And the rest of us are truck horses?

question: Now the lady said you may go Well, I tell you, yesterday when I was here, I had one of your books in my hand, and when I got outside, I realized I still had your book in my hand. So as long as I had your book in my hand, I thought I might as well take it home and read it. This morning, I got up and put your book in my hand, and here's your book in your hand. Yeah, that was considerate of me. I recommend you read it. Well, maybe it's a bit heavy for you. Perhaps if you'd like something lighter - something with a touch of romance Just listen to this
answer: I'm not interested. Smythe will open the door. Where did you get those letters?

question: I stole them when I was interviewing Babykins about Bobo.
answer: I suppose you're going to print them?

question: No - give you another guess. So, it's obvious, huh?
answer: Will you step into the library? What are your initials - Mr. - er

question: Smith. Stewart Smith. My friends call me Stew. It's an injustice too because I hold my liquor all right.
answer: Will - uh - five thousand be enough?

question: For what?
answer: For the letters, of course.

question: Gee, you shouldn't do that, Miss Schuyler. That's all right for your lawyer friend, but you shouldn't go around thinking you can buy people.
answer: I don't know how to thank you. Mother'll be so grateful - she'll probably want to kiss you.

question: Your mother will want to kiss me? Give me back my letters.
answer: You're a peculiar person. Why the other day I pleaded with you not to send in that story and I won't even pretend it isn't a very great favor. I wish there was something I could do for you

question: Well, you could make this table a little - uh - a little less wide.
answer: Oh, you fool!

question: After years of research, I finally discovered that I was the only guy in the world who hadn't written a play, so believe it or not, in my spare time I'm now writing a play.
answer: Really?

question: Yeah, I haven't figured out the plot yet, but it's laid in a Siberian village.
answer: You're a bit eccentric, aren't you?

question: Me? No - most ordinary guy in the world, me. Only one thing wrong with me
answer: You don't wear garters!

question: Naw, that's just a symbol of my independence. I'm color blind. That's what's wrong - I'm color blind. I've been sitting here for a half hour looking at you and I don't know yet whether your eyes are blue or violet.
answer: I'm just beginning to believe that something could be done with you.

question: Say, you could do anything with me you wanted to. Putty - just putty, that's me.
answer: Not if you're going to lose any sleep about it. Now, how would you like themopen like this?

question: Where were you yesterday?
answer: Oh, Stew and I went for a long ride. Just the same, he's going to be a different person when I get through with him.

question: When you get through with him?
answer: Yes, it'll be a very interesting experiment. Exactly.

question: Now, Anne, you remember how much it cost to get rid of that baseball player?
answer: You don't seem to understand that this one's different. He has brains. You? Oh, don't go serious on me, Dexter. Hello, Natalie. Mr. Stewart Smith . . . Miss Montgomery, Mrs. Eames, Mrs. Radcliff, Mr. Radcliff

question: Throw me out - because I'm beginning to get goofy ideas, and they concern you, Anne.
answer: What? Oh, I'll be surprised, eh? Listen if there's any news in that sheet that I haven't thrown in the wastepaper basket, I'll eat it.

question: Me?
answer: You double-crossing hound! Come over here!

question: Now listen boss, if you're going to kick about that expense account It has been alleged - yes
answer: You wouldn't know news if you fell into a mess of it, nose first. So you're the bright lad that's never been scooped! I've heard of people being scooped on their own funerals, but this! Holy mackerel! Why, it's news when Anne Schuyler gets her fingernails manicured, but this! She gets married to one of our own reporters and the Tribune beat us to it!

question: No, no - it's true, all right, only we didn't want to get it in print yet, that's all.
answer: Why not?

question: Well, you see, I've acquired one of those new mother-in-laws, and we were afraid she wouldn't understand the whole idea. So we were going to wait till she went to Europe.
answer: What do I care about your mother-in-law! You're still working for this paper, aren't you! Or are you?

question: Yes, sir.
answer: Well, it's your business to get news! And here you had a story right in your own lap and you let the Tribune scoop us on it. Making a first class Grade A monkey out of me. If it ever happens again - just don't bother about coming back. That's all.

question: Thanks for your congratulations. What's the matter with you mugs? Can't a guy get married without all this? Well, well, well! Gallagher, old pal! There you are. What did you run away for?
answer: I didn't run away.

question: Sure, you ran away. Aren't you going to congratulate a guy? Thanks, thanks.
answer: I hope you'll be very happy.

question: Oh sure, we'll be happy. What's the matter with your eyes?
answer: It's the smoke. Who me? She wouldn't want to meet me. I'm just an old load of hay.

question: Ah! Thank you, Joe.
answer: Do you think your wife would walk up three flights of stairs just to eat out of paper plates?

question: Who - Anne? Sure, Anne would love that.
answer: Remember, she's a Schuyler.

question: Now get this, Gallagher - Smith. That's the name. Well, if she doesn't want to come, I'll come down alone.
answer: Oh, I'll call you up some time. And if your social duties permit - why -

question: Cut that out. Just because I'm married - there's no reason for that.
answer: What's the Benedict looking for in the newspaper - his lost freedom?

question: Gallagher and myself just came over here to do a little work on a story
answer: Well, when are you quitting?

question: Quitting? I'm not thinking about quitting.
answer: I take it you don't have to work for a living any more Mr. Schuyler . Is that so?

question: That's so.
answer: Anne Schuyler's in the Blue Book - you're not even in the phone book. Think that one over, sucker. Blah! It's like a giraffe marrying a monkey.

question: A what?
answer: You heard me. A bird in a gilded cage.

question: Aw, you've been reading a lot of cheap tabloids. Anne and myself are going to move downtown in a nice little flat, we're gonna forget all about this social stuff, and we're gonna be known as Mr. and Mrs. Stew Smith. How do you like that? Yeah, live on my salary - that is, until I finish writing my play. My play.
answer: The one about the Siberian bloodhound?

question: Siberian bloodhound? No. That's been all rewritten. It's laid in Araby now.
answer: Araby?

question: Sure.
answer: Araby, my eye! Well, I'm sorry to see a good reporter go blooey

question: I'm not quitting!
answer: No?

question: No!
answer: Don't pay attention to him, Stew. He doesn't know what he's talking about.

question: Pay attention? I'm not paying any attention to him. You think that guy could get me upset? Hah! Not that mug. He's a tough mug - hard, cynical. He doesn't know the fine things in life - that guy.
answer: Sure - I think so, Stew.

question: I knew you would, pal.
answer: How is her family going to feel about it?

question: I'm glad.
answer: He can bend!

question: Come here baby! I haven't seen you for three hours. You're neglecting me already
answer: What's the matter? Something I et, no doubt. Egg marks the spot

question: You ought to get some new ties, Stewart.
answer: I don't need any new ties. I've got another tie - I've got another one besides this one. And it's a pip, too. There's only one thing wrong with it. You know what that is? It has a little weakness for gravy, and once in a while it leans a little toward ketchup. Of course that's only in its weaker moments. When you move down to my place, I'll show it to you.

question: Your place?
answer: Yeah. Oh, it's great. Of course it doesn't compare with this coliseum of yours here, but 'twill serve m'lady, 'twill serve. When 'we' . . .? You mean, you'd like to have me live here in your house?

question: Sure. We can have the whole left wing and be all by ourselves all the time.
answer: Oh, Mother will give us the blue room. You haven't a red room, have you? Well, bless her heart. Wouldn't that be nice! My, oh my - six rooms and two baths and a blue room. I guess she would let us have the right wing if we needed it, wouldn't she?

question: But we don't need it, I'm sure.
answer: I see, we won't need that. Plenty of room, plenty of room.

question: Of course I am Stewart.
answer: Now let's get this settled

question: You have the cutest nose I've
answer: Never mind my nose. What kind of a chump do you think I am? You think I'm going to live here in your house - on your dough? What do you think my friends would all say? Don't be silly. I'd get the razzing of my life for that. 'A bird in a gilded cage' - that's what I'd be. Not me. Oh no, not me!

question: What do you think my friends would say if they found me in a little cheap flat?
answer: It isn't cheap. It's nice. Wait a minute. I'll do anything you ask me, Anne, but I will not live Nevertheless, whether the nose is sweet or not, I'm not going to live in your house. You may as well get that straight. You do want me to be happy, don't you? Then I'm not going to live in your house

question: It isn't cheap. It's nice. Wait a minute. I'll do anything you ask me, Anne, but I will not live Nevertheless, whether the nose is sweet or not, I'm not going to live in your house. You may as well get that straight. You do want me to be happy, don't you? Then I'm not going to live in your house
answer: Mr. Smith, sir Mr. Smith, sir! Mr. Smith, sir How do you like your bath, sir?

question: I like my bath all right. How do you like your bath? Who are you? You're my what?
answer: Your valet, sir.

question: Thank you, thank you, thank you! I'll do that for you some time. That's very sweet. Say listen, what did you say your name was?
answer: Dawson, sir.

question: Dawson, huh? Was I very drunk last night?
answer: Drunk, sir?

question: Yes. I must have been pretty much plastered if I hired a valet.
answer: Oh, but you didn't engage me, sir.

question: Who did engage you then, if I didn't engage you? What are you doing with my pants Did you take anything out of those pants?
answer: Oh no, sir!

question: What are you doing fooling around in here?
answer: Miss Schuyler - I mean, Mrs. Smith - she engaged me this morning, sir.

question: Hmmm. So Mrs. Smith engaged me a valley, huh? That's very nice of Mrs. Smith - to engage me a valley.
answer: Thank you, sir.

question: But not for me! Though I like you well enough. You're a nice fellow. You're all right. But I'm sorry I don't need any valleys today.
answer: Oh, but indeed you do, sir, if you don't mind my saying so. A gentleman's gentleman, as it were. Someone to draw your bath, lay out your clothes, help to dress you - it's really most essential, sir. Quite so. Quite.

question: Now I'm sorry. I appreciate your efforts. But I don't need anybody to help me button my pants - I've been buttoning my pants for thirty years all right, and I can button 'em with one hand as a matter of fact.
answer: Now Mr. Smith, now please

question: You've got a nice face, Dawson, you wouldn't want anything to happen to your face, would you?
answer: Oh no, sir

question: All right, outside!
answer: I think I understand, sir. You mean you want me to go? No, sir. No!

question: Wait a minute, what's this?
answer: That's a canary, sir.

question: That's a canary! Who brought that in here? Canary, huh? Go on, get that out of here. Get that out of here!
answer: Yes sir!

question: Say, who is this mug?
answer: I've got a present. Shut your eyes. Keep 'em closed. I know you're going to love them. Do you like them?

question: Got my initials on them too. They're cute. They're nice little things - what do you do with them?
answer: You wear them of course, silly.

question: Oh no. No, no. Not me. I haven't worn these things for Years.
answer: I know that.

question: Besides I'd look foolish. I couldn't look Gallagher in the face.
answer: Darling, I don't care whether you can look Gallagher in the face or not, but you're gonna be a good boy and wear garters.

question: Honey, I love you. I'll eat spinach for you. I'll go to the dentist twice a year for you. I'll wash behind my ears for you. But I will never wear garters!
answer: Oh, yes you will my dear - oh, yes you will my dear - you'll eat spinach but you'll wear garters too!

question: Oh, you can't carry a tune - you can't carry a tune - all you are good for is to sit and spoon, spoon. Oh no, I won't wear garters
answer: Oh yes you will wear garters

question: Oh yes - of course. Miss Gallagher?
answer: Yes.

question: I'm Miss Wilson - Mrs. Schuyler's social secretary.
answer: I was sent from the Post in place of our social editor.

question: Yes, of course. Miss Ramsey telephoned me. Well, what would you like to have?
answer: Why, a list of the guests. That's the usual thing, isn't it?

question: Yes, of course. I'll get it for you
answer: Yes, thank you.

question: That's a lovely dress.
answer: Thank you.

question: Mr. Smith? Oh, you mean Ann Schuyler's husband?
answer: Yes.

question: He's probably very tired. You see, he's had to meet all these people personally tonight.
answer: I bet.

question: You newspaper people have a lot of fun with him, don't you? What is it you call him - the Cinderella Man? There's the Spanish Ambassador.
answer: You know, he looks like one.

question: Yes?
answer: Thanks. Mr. Smith, I've read some of your plays and I'd like an autograph.

question: Thanks. Mr. Smith, I've read some of your plays and I'd like an autograph.
answer: Well, well! If it isn't my old friend! Turn around, gal! Let's get a look at you.

question: There you are!
answer: Well, daughter of the slums - how did you get out of the ghetto?

question: I'm pinch-hitting for our society editor tonight. I wanted to see some life in the raw.
answer: Aw, you wanted to see some life in the raw, huh? Well gal, I'm afraid we ain't got no raw life up here.

question: Well, I'll have to look someplace else.
answer: No, no! Maybe we could interest you in some well done butterflies, or perhaps some slightly fried pansies, or better still, some stuffed shirts. And guaranteed every one of them will give you a good stiff pain in the neck. Gee Gallagher, do you look good! What are you doing to yourself?

question: Nothing.
answer: What did you do to that hair? And where did you get that dress?

question: I dyed one and washed the other. Don't turn around now - but there's a very beautiful girl up there who seems to be staring at us.
answer: Staring at us?

question: My mistake - she's glaring.
answer: Must be my wife. It is my wife. Hi Anne. Don't go away. Stay right there, because I'm going to bring a friend up I want you to meet. Anne, prepare yourself for the treat of your life. This is Gallagher. Sure - my pal on the paper. She's subbing for the society editor tonight.

question: Hello, there, Meadows! I want to see Stew Smith. Oh excuse me - I mean Mr. Smith.
answer: Pardon me, Mr. Smith is engaged. We are having a reception here this evening

question: Oh, a party! Great, great! Jolly times and merry pranks. That's me. I'm a guy who loves parties. You know a beautiful pair of shoulders! But listen now, as a favor, will you please make it snappy, Laughing Waters, and tell Stew Smith I gotta see him because if you don't my whole family's going to die.
answer: I'll tell Mr. Smith at once, sir. Have a seat.

question: Well, I got a seat, but I have no place to put it.
answer: Pardon me, sir, but I've heard that one before.

question: No. I was just looking at it. Pretty, ain't it? I was just looking for the price tag.
answer: What do you want?

question: Oh, nothing. I just blew over - I wanted to see how the old newshound looked made up for a gentleman. Oh boy, I'd love it.
answer: How's that? Is that so? Well, have you seen enough - or would you like a photograph?

question: A photograph? What's the matter? Hasn't mama had you done in oils yet?
answer: Now get this mug. You've got the kind of chin I just love to touch. And if you don't get out of here, I'm going to hang one right on it.

question: Take it easy! Take it easy, Dempsey. Just relax, my boy, relax and open your pores. I bring a message from Garcia.
answer: Yeah?

question: Good morning, Mother. Didn't I tell you that he'd be marvelous. Everybody thought he was so charming last night.
answer: I was so worried for fear he'd knock over a vase or something. I must have acted like an idiot.

question: Oh, the usual thing. Blah, blah, blah attended the blah, blah reception and wore the same blah, blah things. You don't have anything to complain about, Mother. He was all right last night, wasn't he? I told you not to worry about him.
answer: It was a miracle. The man was ill or something.

question: Mother!
answer: I knew it! I knew it! I felt it in my bones!

question: I knew it! I knew it! I felt it in my bones!
answer: Good morning, everybody

question: Have you seen this?
answer: Yes - the worm!

question: I beg your pardon?
answer: He's a worm - and I'm gonna step on him!

question: I've tried to stop the evening papers, but it's useless.
answer: You quit trying to stop anybody

question: Well, at best you might deny it.
answer: Why deny it? The more you deny, the more they print. Let them alone! The thing to do is to sit still and keep our traps shut.

question: Traps shut!
answer: Certainly! I'll take care of this guy Bingy myself, personally.

question: Oh, you can't disappoint all the women. After all it isn't every day they get to see a famous round-the-world flier. Are you complaining? We're waiting for my husband
answer: I poisoned him.

question: Stop trying to be funny, and get ready, will you?
answer: I'm not going!

question: What are you talking about?
answer: I'm talking about - I'm not going out. Go downstairs, and tell them - anything. Tell them I'm not going. Tell them I'm not home. Yes, I'll tell you - for the same reason I've never wanted to go out with those social parasites, those sweet-smelling fashion plates. I don't like them. They bore me. They give me the jitters. Yes, I'm talking about your friends, and they still give me the jitters.

question: Well, are you going - or aren't you?
answer: Anne, come here. Listen I'll tell you what. Let's you and me sneak out all by ourselves Think of the fun we can have - we'll sneak down the back stairs and get in the valet's Ford. How's that?

question: Will you stop being silly, Stewart?
answer: I don't mean the newspaper fellows that you don't like. Another gang I know - you'd love them. They're writers and musicians and artists - a great crowd of people - people who do great things. People who are worthwhile.

question: Meaning, my friends aren't worthwhile, I suppose?
answer: Oh, they're all right, Anne. But I And that, my friends, is what is known as the society belle telling ex-star-newspaper-reporter to go to - how-have-you-been, Mr. Smith!

question: Oh, they're all right, Anne. But I And that, my friends, is what is known as the society belle telling ex-star-newspaper-reporter to go to - how-have-you-been, Mr. Smith!
answer: Did you call, sir?

question: Smythe, come here. I want to talk to you. Shhh! Do you hear something?
answer: Yes, sir.

question: You try it. Yeah. No, no. Give it more volume. No, that's enough. I just wanted you to get the idea. Now you know. This house is haunted. Yes. Have you looked in the closets all over . . .?
answer: Yes, sir.

question: Found no skeletons?
answer: No, sir.

question: It's haunted just the same.
answer: Yes, sir.

question: Smythe, what do you do with yourself - I mean, when you're not carrying those double-strength - what do you do with yourself?
answer: Well, sir, I putter.

question: Smythe! I mean - when you're alone and want to amuse yourself, then what?
answer: I just putter.

question: Hmmm, you just putter. Do you have to have a putter to putter?
answer: Oh no, sir. I putter with me hands.

question: Well, isn't that nice? You just go right ahead and putter with your hands. That's all right. How do you do it?
answer: Well sir, I'll show you. That's puttering, sir.

question: No! Well, well, well! That's all right, if you like it. Can anybody do that?
answer: Oh no, sir. Some people are natural putterers. Others can never master it.

question: Oh my. You mean, some people are born and never will become putterers?
answer: Yes sir.

question: Oh my, wouldn't that be tragic? To know that you could never be a putterer.
answer: Yes sir.

question: How about me? Do you think if I concentrated and put my whole soul into it, that some day I might be a putterer?
answer: You sir? Uh-uh. You could never be a putterer. Not a good putterer, sir.

question: Well, if I couldn't be a good putterer, I wouldn't want to putter. But why? What makes you think I couldn't be a good putterer?
answer: Well sir, to be a putterer, one's mind must be at ease. A person with a problem could never be a putterer. For instance, sir, a fish can putter in water but not on land because he'd be out of place. An eagle can putter around a rugged mountaintop but not in a cage, because he'd be restless and unhappy. Now sir, if you will pardon me, with all due respect, sir, as a Smythe to a Smith, you are an eagle in a cage.

question: A bird in a gilded cage?
answer: Yes.

question: That's all I wanted to know! Hello, Gallagher old pal. How are you, old pal?
answer: Oh, hello Stew. I'm pretty good, can't complain. How's our gentleman of leisure?

question: I'm on the coast of Norway and I can't get out - will you come and get me out of the coast of Norway?
answer: Oh, your play. Hmmm, Act One, Scene One

question: Yeah. Come on, don't be silly.
answer: Okay.

question: Hello, Hank. How are you?
answer: Fine, but kinda thirsty.

question: Come right in - I'll get you a drink.
answer: Okay - you remember Joe

question: Sure.
answer: I sort of invited him along to bend an elbow. You don't mind, do you?

question: It's all right. Bring him in.
answer: Come in, Joe. It's all right.

question: Hello, Joe. No, no, bring him in. The more the merrier. Hello, Johnson. Glad to see you. Come in, kid. You brought two of the boys? That's all right. Bring them in. What's the difference? I'm sorry nobody could come.
answer: The rest of the gang had to get out the morning edition - but they'll be down later.

question: No, it's just little Bingy Baker.
answer: Excuse me, Gallagher. I wouldn't miss this one for the world.

question: Fire water all right. Well, Stew, that's all thrashed out. By golly, I'm surely glad to see that you're not really sore. You know our racket - after all, news is news.
answer: Sure, sure. That's all right. That was a great story, Bingy. A great story - wish I'd printed it.

question: I gave you the breaks, didn't I? That hairy chest story!
answer: You know what I should do with you? I should sock you right in that funny little nose.

question: How far have you gotten?
answer: Well, I've just been able to get off that Norway coast - so far. Never even been to New Madrid.

question: Then how do you expect to write about it?
answer: Oh - draw on my imagination, I suppose.

question: Did Conrad draw on his imagination?
answer: Did who?

question: Conrad.
answer: What do you know about Conrad?

question: I don't know a thing about him, but isn't he the one you're always yelling about?
answer: Gosh, you look cute.

question: Isn't he the one that always writes about things - only the things he knows about?
answer: Right.

question: Didn't he go to sea before he wrote about it?
answer: Right.

question: Then why don't you write about something you know? Write about yourself and Anne. The poor boy who marries a rich girl - now there's a swell theme.
answer: Gee, that's an idea, Gallagher. That's an idea there. I wonder now . . .

question: Oh, sure. She'd make a beautiful heroine
answer: You could be something.

question: Here you are.
answer: All right, thanks. Now, let's see. How will I start? Hey pal, how would you start?

question: Now Gallagher, if we could only get a great scene - a tremendously emotional scene - some-
answer: Nope - afraid I'm all out of tricks tonight.

question: Now, we've got it right up to where the boy's wearing his white spats and going to teas and the frau enters - how's that?
answer: Very good.

question: I think you should, Miss Gallagher.
answer: Wait a minute, Gallagher. What's the idea, Anne?

question: The idea is simply this - that I want those people to leave here immediately.
answer: Now wait a minute. Aren't you being a little unreasonable?

question: Unreasonable! Have you any idea what the place looks like downstairs? Do you expect me to stand here and see this place turned into a cheap barroom?
answer: Now wait, don't get excited, Anne. There's no reason for that. Perhaps the boys have had a little too much to drink. That's all right. I'm sorry. I'll go right down and throw them out. That's no reason for you to take this attitude. After all, I certainly have a right to invite a few of my friends to my house, haven't I? I suppose I've been boarding out this past year. and if it's all the same to you, I'm moving out.

question: Stewart! You can't walk out of here like this.
answer: Oh I can't? Who's going to stop me? I'd like to see somebody stop me. If you think I'm going to stick around this joint just to look at this mausoleum, not on your life! You're going to make no stuffed shirt out of me. Now what do you think of that?

question: Hey, Gallagher!
answer: Yeah?

question: How about my breakfast? How do you expect me to ring a curtain down on an empty stomach?
answer: It'll be ready in a minute.

question: Don't be sorry. Just get the breakfast, that's all.
answer: Hello, Smith. I suppose you know why I came?

question: No, I have no idea - unless some of the silver-ware is missing.
answer: Now don't be absurd, Smith

question: Surely, come right in. Surely, sit down. If I had known you were coming, I would have thrown you up a waffle.
answer: I don't eat waffles.

question: You don't.
answer: Anne asked me to come and see you about the divorce.

question: Listen Grayson, I've got 106 bucks and 75 cents in the bank. Now Anne can have any part of that she wants, but she'd better hurry because I'm spending it awfully fast.
answer: We should like to know how much you would want to That's putting it crudely, but I beg your pardon.

question: Unconscious. You know, when you don't know anything. Your natural state. There are some people - you can't buy their self-respect for a bucket of shekels - well, I happen to be one of those guys.
answer: Yes.
